I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  With the enactment of the new Electricity Law in November 2004, the Government of 
Viet  Nam  initiated  a  far-reaching  power  sector  reform  program.  The  Government  has 
incorporated the key recommendations of TA 3763-VIE1 into the reform strategy and has 
requested  further  technical  assistance  (TA)  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to 
implement the initial steps of the reform strategy. The proposed TA was included in the Viet 
Nam Country Strategy and Program Update (2005–2006) as the Power Sector Restructuring 
Advisory TA, and at the request of the Government it has been replaced by the Power Market 
Design Advisory TA.2 Fact-finding was undertaken in May 2005, and the mission reached 
understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  scope,  approach,  cost  estimates,  and 
implementation arrangement for the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  As  a  result  of  Viet  Nam’s  sustained  economic  growth  of  more  than  7%  per  year, 
increasing industrialization, and low initial per capita consumption of electricity, the growth in 
demand for electricity has averaged more than 14% per year during the past decade and a 
similar growth rate is expected in the medium term. Electricity sales in 2010 are forecast to be 
100 to 112 terawatt-hours, with peak demand of 17.5 to 19.5 gigawatts (GW), compared with 
electricity sales of 40 gigawatt-hours and peak demand of 8.3 GW in 2004. To meet this rapid 
increase in the demand for power, installed capacity needs to be increased from 10.8 GW in 
2004 to 22.6 GW by 2010. The total investment requirement for the power sector for 2004–2010 
is estimated to be $19.0 billion, with power generation alone requiring $11.8 billion. The main 
challenge facing the power sector is mobilizing adequate financial resources without adversely 
affecting the sector’s financial viability.  
 
3.  State policy for the sector as enunciated in the new Electricity Law is to develop a power 
market based on principles of transparency and competition to achieve economic efficiency, to 
attract investments from both state and nonstate sectors to the sector, and to ensure legitimate 
rights for the sector’s consumers and investors. The law further states that the state’s monopoly 
in the sector will be limited to power transmission, national load dispatch, and strategically 
important large power plants, leaving power distribution and nonstrategic power generation to 
potential  private  sector  investors.  The  law  specifically  encourages  investments  by  foreign 
private sector investors and joint ventures between foreign investors and domestic enterprises 
in the power sector. To give effect to these objectives, the Ministry of Industry (MOI) is entrusted 
with establishing a competitive power market.  
 
4.  The power sector is currently dominated by Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN), a state-owned 
cooperation that accounts for more than 85% of power generation, bulk power transmission, 
and power distribution either directly or through intermediaries in some rural areas. EVN is 
organized into strategic business units, with the units engaged in power distribution considered 
to be independent accounting units, that is, profit centers, while transmission and generation 
units  are  viewed  as  dependent  accounting  units,  that  is,  cost  centers.  Private  sector 
participation in the sector is limited to a couple of large natural gas-based thermal power plants 
and several small oil-fired thermal and hydropower plants. Several other power generation

projects are under construction that have been developed by state-owned enterprises other 
than EVN.  
 
5.  According to EVN’s draft corporate restructuring plan,3 EVN-owned power plants would 
be converted into independent accounting units, that is, profit centers, and some EVN-owned 
power plants would be equitized, namely, partially privatized. The Government is contemplating 
public offerings through the stock market as well as direct sales to strategic investors. However, 
EVN is proposing to retain three large, multipurpose hydropower projects with a combined 
capacity of 3,000 MW (30% of installed capacity at present) as dependent units. The four 
transmission units currently structured as dependent units of EVN would be merged to form a 
wholly-owned EVN subsidiary that would own and operate the transmission network. EVN’s 
stakes in the equitized provincial distribution utilities would be held through the seven existing 
regional  power  companies.  These  regional  power  companies  would  be  converted  from 
independent  accounting  units  to  wholly-owned  subsidiaries  of  EVN.  EVN’s  cooperate 
restructuring program is expected to be completed by 2008. 
 
6.  The road map for electricity market establishment and development prepared by MOI for 
the prime minister’s approval envisages that the corporate restructuring of EVN will establish the 
necessary conditions for initiating of the power market. The first phase of the proposed road 
map is to set up an internal pilot market for EVN-owned power plants and the power plants in 
which EVN holds a dominant share. Existing independent power producers (IPPs) and the three 
strategic multipurpose hydropower plants will not take part in the internal market. The IPPs will 
be dispatched according to the power purchase agreements between EVN and the IPPs. During 
the first phase, the market rules as well as the regulatory, technical, and commercial institutions 
and capacity required for operating the second phase of the proposed power market (a single 
buyer-based competitive generation market with the participation of non-EVN power plants) 
would be developed and pilot tested.  
 
7.  The Electricity Regulatory Authority (ERA) for the power sector would be established 
within MOI as a separate institution. The key functions of the ERA during the first and second 
stages will include (i) issuing licenses to sector entities and enforcing them; (ii) advising the 
minister of industry on market structure and industry restructuring policy; (iii) establishing the 
tariff-setting principles, including transfer pricing between sector entities; (iv) developing tariffs 
for regulated activities; (v) approving the power purchase agreements of the single buyer; (vi) 
ensuring  the  procurement  of  adequate  new  generation  and  transmission  capacity;  (vii) 
monitoring the progress of implementation of new generation and transmission projects; and 
(viii) monitoring the functioning of the power market. The Electricity Law does not clearly define 
the enforcement mechanism for regulatory actions and expectations are that the official decision 
establishing the regulator will clarify the enforcement powers of the ERA. 
 
8.  During the first and second phases of the proposed power market, the competition will 
be  only  among  the  sellers,  that  is,  power  plants.  The  single  buyer  will  sell  electricity  to 
distribution companies and large consumers at regulated prices. EVN’s internal power market 
has started in the second half of 2005, with the competitive generation market starting in 2009. 
One of the key issues is the degree of independence of the single buyer and the system 
operator from the rest of EVN in the event that EVN continues to own and control a significant 
stake in equitized power plants. This will require transparent rules for market operation, for

dispatching of power plants, and for settlement and appropriate regulatory oversight. If these 
conditions cannot be guaranteed, the single buyer and the system operator will have to be 
separated from EVN.  
 
9.  The responsibility for planning and procuring new generation capacity will be transferred 
to the newly set up single buyer and ERA. As the agency responsible for steering the reform 
process and for managing the sector on behalf of the state, MOI is expected to ensure that 
adequate generation capacity is procured to keep pace with the rapid increase in the demand 
for power. The contractual arrangements for the new generation capacity to be procured during 
the first phase from the state as well as from nonstate entities will have to be consistent with the 
functioning of the proposed competitive generation market in the second phase. One of the key 
challenges is to provide adequate reassurance to potential investors in the context of ongoing 
reforms and an incipient power market without compromising the flexibility required in power 
purchase agreements for effective functioning of the proposed power market. 
 
10.  The power sector is a key area for ADB assistance to Viet Nam. ADB’s past investments 
in  the  sector  focused  on  power  transmission  and  distribution,  whereas  future  investment 
projects are likely to be in power generation. These investment loans have been accompanied 
by TA and policy dialogue to improve the sector’s efficiency and the investment climate for 
private sector investors. The proposed TA will provide strategic advice to the Government 
during the initial phase of implementation of the road map, which was prepared based on ADB 
TA  3763.4 It  is  envisaged  to  provide  further  assistance as  the  Government  proceeds  with 
establishing the power market. It will aim at developing market instruments for the evolving 
power market and at institutional capacity building for market entities such as the regulatory 
agency, the system and market operator, and others.  
 
11.  The power market reform program during 2006–2010 consists of (i) setting up the power 
market and designing market rules for a single buyer market, (ii) establishing the regulating 
agency  for  the  sector,  (iii)  undertaking  the  corporate  restructuring  of  EVN  to  meet  the 
requirements of a single buyer market, and (iv) procuring new generation capacity consistent 
with a least-cost power development plan. These activities need to be carried out in a consistent 
and coherent manner, and slippage in any of these activities would affect the effectiveness of 
the reform program.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The proposed TA focuses on (i) designing the market structure, (ii) devising a framework 
for regulatory instruments and market rules, and (iii) preparing guidelines for procuring new 
generation capacity. The main purpose of the TA is to provide guidance to the Government in 
making strategic decisions regarding the market structure, the role of EVN and its subsidiaries 
and  the  relationship  among  these  entities,  the  nature  of  the  regulatory  regime  and  key 
regulatory mechanisms, and the terms of power purchase arrangements for new power plants 
and equitized power plants. 
 
13.  The main outcome of the TA would be a series of technical papers addressing these 
issues in the context of Viet Nam’s specific circumstances and current Government policy for 
the  sector.  These  papers  will  be  discussed  with  relevant  Government  counterparts  and 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Road Map for Power Sector Reform. 
Manila. (TA 3763-VIE, approved on 6 November 2004, for $400,000.)

4   
stakeholders, including international development agencies active in the sector, before they are 
finalized.  The  TA  will  (i)  recommend  general  structuring  of  the  power  sector  to  meet  the 
requirements of a competitive generation market, (ii) design the market structure for competitive 
generation market, and (iii) design the regulatory framework for the competitive generation 
market.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The structure of the electricity sector industry in the future will depend largely on the 
proposed restructuring of EVN, because EVN is currently the dominant entity in the industry. 
Hence the proposed strategy for the corporate restructuring of EVN is critically important to the 
success of the proposed electricity market. The consultants will propose the extent to which 
EVN’s generation assets should be separated from the rest of EVN; the maximum equity stake 
EVN should have in the nonstrategic generation units, if any; and the number of generation 
companies to be set up to own power plants currently owned by EVN prior to the establishment 
of  the  competitive  generation  market.  These  proposals  will  take  Viet  Nam’s  specific 
circumstances  into  account.  The  ownership  and  management  structures  for  the  strategic 
multipurpose hydropower projects such as Hoa Binh will be proposed taking specifics of these 
projects  into  account  and  the  concerns  of  relevant  nonpower  stakeholders.  The  proposed 
program for equitizing EVN’s generation assets will be reviewed in the context of investors’ 
interest in sector and capital market development in Viet Nam.  
 
15.  EVN’s National Load Dispatch Center and Power Market Department are expected to 
evolve into the system operator and market operator and the single buyer, respectively. The 
consultants will make recommendations regarding the structure and ownership of the single 
buyer and the system operator and market operator and whether these entities could remain 
within EVN or whether they should be independent of EVN. In the event of the Government 
deciding to keep the single buyer and the system operator and market operator as part of EVN, 
the consultants will make recommendations for addressing the potential conflicts of interest 
caused by EVN’s ownership stakes in power generation through regulatory oversight, firewalls, 
and other measures.  
 
16.  The consultants will review experience with EVN’s internal market, which was set up in 
July 2005, and draw lessons that could be helpful in the design of the competitive generation 
market with the participation of non-EVN power plants. The consultants will determine the 
detailed set of prerequisites required to move from the EVN internal market to the competitive 
generation market. This will include (i) the progress of EVN’s restructuring program; (ii) the 
progress in establishing key market entities, such as the regulatory agency, the single buyer, 
and the system operator; and (iii) the finalization of the basic framework for key market tools, 
such  as  grid,  settlement,  and  bidding  codes.  The  consultants  will  identify  the  additional 
requirements to be met before a balancing market, that is, a spot market,5 is introduced to the 
competitive generation market. 
  
17.  ERA is expected to be adequately staffed with competent personnel, and the regulatory 
instruments  will  be  prepared  prior  to  the  transition  to  the  competitive  generation  market 
supported by follow-up TAs. The TA will also recommend key aspects of the regulatory regime 
for  the  competitive  generation  market.  This  will  involve  defining  how  the  regulator  should 
exercise  its  powers  under  the  Electricity  Law  and  the  relevant  decrees  for  regulating  the 
                                                 
5  A market mechanism whereby generators submit bids on a daily basis to supply electricity and meet the demand 
not covered by long-term contracts between generators and the single buyer.

5
functioning of the market and the performance of key market institutions, such as the single 
buyer, the system operator, and the transmission company. The intent is to provide a level 
playing field for the competing generators, including regulatory oversight in monitoring the 
dispatching of power plants. The framework for information flow between market players and 
the regulator and the templates for licenses to be issued to market players will be developed 
under the TA. The TA will also define mechanisms for regulatory approval of power purchase 
agreements for new plants and for power plants that are being equitized. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $625,000 equivalent, of which the foreign 
exchange cost is $420,000 and the local currency cost is $205,000 equivalent. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent, comprising the entire foreign exchange cost 
and $80,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance the remaining $125,000 equivalent of 
local currency costs through in-kind contributions by the executing and implementing agencies 
of office accommodation and facilities, local communication facilities, and counterpart staff. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are provided in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The TA will require about 18 person-months of international consulting services and 18 
person-months of domestic consulting services. An international consulting firm will be recruited 
by MOI using the quality- and cost-based selection method based on a simplified technical 
proposal in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development 
Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of 
domestic consultants. This TA is not envisaged to involve any procurement. The TA will be 
implemented over an 8-month period commencing in March 2006 and ending in October 2006. 
The outline terms of reference for the consultants are provided in Appendix 3. MOI will be the 
Executing Agency for the TA and ERA, when established, will be the implementing agency. The 
Government and ADB have agreed to include this TA as one of the projects under the pilot 
study for the delegation of consultant recruitment and supervision to MOI.6  
20.  MOI will set up a working group consisting of representatives of the main stakeholders 
and a donor coordinating committee to provide feedback on the main outputs of the consultants. 
The key outputs of the TA will be presented to the stakeholders in the form of a series of 
workshops and the feedback received will be incorporated into the final recommendations. The 
Agence Française de Développement has offered to finance a resident adviser to help MOI 
implement the initial work program to set up market institutions and undertake capacity building 
and training of employees of key institutions involved in the proposed power market. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Power Market Design, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Implementation of the technical assistance (TA) will require the services of a team of 
consultants  with  expertise  in  power  system  operation,  power  markets,  regulation  of  power 
markets, and Viet Nam’s commercial law. An international firm of consultants will be engaged for 
this assignment and will be expected to work with the domestic consultants to be recruited by the 
Ministry of Industry. The international firm of consultants will propose the international experts for 
the assignment and the domestic consultants to be recruited by the Ministry of Industry. The 
consultants are expected to undertake consultations with Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN) and with 
non-EVN stakeholders in the sector, which consist of independent power producers (IPPs) and 
developers of new IPPs, fuel suppliers, domestic and international financiers of IPPs, and large 
consumers. The feedback received will be discussed with policy makers and will be included in 
the consultants’ recommendations as appropriate.  
 
 
A.   Recommendation  on  General  Structuring  of  the  Power  Sector  to  Meet  the 
Requirements  of  a  Competitive  Generation  Market  (international consultant: senior 
power sector reform specialist and team leader [4 person-months]; domestic consultant: 
Viet Nam power sector expert [4 person-months]) 
 
2.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Make recommendations regarding EVN’s role in key market institutions such as the 
system  operator,  the  transmission  company,  and  the  single  buyer.  If  the 
Government  decides  to  have  these  institutions  within  EVN,  make  specific 
recommendations to address potential conflicts of interest and to ensure a level 
playing field between power plants partially or wholly owned by EVN and non-EVN 
power  plants.  Design  the  management  and  cooperate  governance  structure 
appropriately to achieve this purpose.  
(ii)  Define the roles of the system operator, transmission company, and single buyer in 
the competitive generation market and prepare a detailed list of tasks to be carried 
out  by  each  entity.  Prepare  guidelines  and  templates  to  ensure  transparent 
information and data flow between these market entities.  
(iii)  Review the equitization strategy of EVN’s power plants in the context of capital 
market development and investors’ interest in power sector assets in Viet Nam. 
Make recommendations regarding the grouping of EVN-owned power plants into 
different companies taking into account the specifics of power plants, the efficiency 
of market operations, and the concerns about market dominance.  
(iv)  Make recommendations regarding the extent to which the equitization of EVN 
power plants should proceed before the competitive generation power market can 
be established. Propose terms for off-take arrangements to be offered to equitized 
power plants that would reassure investors while providing the flexibility required in 
the market. Recommend how to deal with signed power purchase agreements and 
standard costs. 
(v)  Make  recommendations  regarding  how  strategically  important  multipurpose 
hydropower projects should be structured in the proposed power market. Propose 
improvements to the operating regime of these power plants, taking into account 
the market’s requirements and the multipurpose nature of these power plants. 
Recommend  whether  these  power  plants  should  be owned  by  EVN  or  by  an 
independent Government-owned company. 
(vi)  Outline a strategy and institutional safeguards oversights to ensure an adequate 
supply of generation capacity and network capacity during the transition period.

B.  Designing  the  Market  Structure  for  Competitive  Generation  Market  (international 
consultants: senior power sector reform specialist [3 person-months] and power market 
operations expert [3 person-months]; domestic consultants: Viet Nam power sector expert 
[3 person-months], power system operations (load dispatch) expert [3 person-months], 
and power system operations (transmission) expert [3 person-months]) 
 
3.  The EVN internal power market started in July 2005 as a learning exercise with the 
participation of eight EVN-owned power plants, and the competitive generation market with the 
participation of all generators is expected to start in 2009. The TA will design the main framework 
for the competitive generation market and the detailed tasks for the consultants include the 
following: 
(i)   Review the experience with EVN’s internal market and assess the market and the 
system operators’ capacity to operate a competitive generation market with the 
participation of non-EVN generators. Review market rules used in EVN’s internal 
market  and  comment  on  their  appropriateness  for  the  competitive  generation 
market  and  the  road  map  for  market  development  already  approved  by  the 
Government.  
(ii)  Recommend  a  time-bound  action  plan  for  initiating  the  competitive  generation 
market  after  critically  analyzing  the  capacity  and  competence  of  the  market 
operators and the structure of the generation sector. This will include a strategy for 
achieving the prerequisites that need to be met before the commencement of the 
market. 
(iii)  Recommend a detailed set of prerequisites to be met before embarking on the 
competitive  generation  market.  These  will  include  (a)  the  progress  of  EVN’s 
restructuring program; (b) the progress in establishing key market entities such as 
the  regulatory  agency,  the  single  buyer,  and  the  system  operator;  (c)  the 
finalization of key market tools such as the grid, settlement, and bidding codes; and 
(d) the requirements for investment in power network infrastructure to meet the 
requirement of the market.  
(iv)  Recommend the main features of the market, including the (a) type and duration of 
the power purchase contracts between the single buyer and different types of 
power plants, and (b) the strategies for purchasing power from hydropower plants 
in a manner that optimizes hydro-thermal coordination in the system.  
(v)  Propose strategies to incorporate the multipurpose hydropower plants and existing 
and future IPPs with long-term power purchase agreements in the proposed power 
market. 
(vi)  Define the main aspects of following technical codes that are required for operating 
the  competitive  generation  market,  (a)  market  rules,  (b)  bidding  code  for 
generators,  (c)  settlement  code,  and  (d)  grid  code  and  provide  guidance  to 
counterpart  staff  on  preparing  these  documents  based  on  international  best 
practice.  
(vii)  Review the rules for unit commitment and economic dispatch and for considering 
transmission constraints in economic dispatch and propose appropriate upgrades 
for the software to meet the requirements of the competitive generation market.  
(viii)  Recommend how the single buyer can procure ancillary services in the competitive 
market.

Appendix 3  11 
(ix)  Recommend  a  strategy  for  moving  from  a  fully  contract-based  market  to  a 
combination of a contract-based market and a spot market. Recommend whether 
the spot market should be further divided into a day-ahead market and a balancing 
market. Prepare the prerequisites for introducing a spot market to the competitive 
generation market.  
  
C.      Designing  the  Regulatory  Framework  for  the  Competitive  Generation  Market 
(international consultants: senior power sector reform specialist [3 person-months], regulatory 
economist  [3  person-months],  project  finance  legal  expert  [2  person-months];  domestic 
consultants: Viet Nam commercial law expert [3 person-months], energy economist [4 person-
months])  
 
4.  The consultants will advise the Ministry of Industry on the key functions of the Electricity 
Regulatory  Authority  that  need  to  be  in  place  prior  to  the  establishment  of  the  competitive 
generation market. To this end, they will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Provide advice and templates for the licenses to be issued to sector entities under 
the Electricity Law.  
(ii)  Establish the tariff-setting principles for monopolistic activities (that is, transmission 
and  distribution  in  concession  areas)  and  for  transfer  pricing  between  sector 
entities. This will include transparent pricing between the single buyer and the 
transmission company, the transmission company and the distribution companies 
and the end user tariffs. Propose strategies for incorporating the Government’s 
subsidy and other policies to the retail tariff-setting principles.  
(iii)  Prepare guidelines for the regulator to exercise its statutory power of ensuring the 
procurement of adequate new generation and transmission capacity and approving 
the  power  purchase  agreements  of  the  single  buyer.  These  should  provide 
adequate assurance to investors in new and equitized power plants while providing 
the flexibility required for operating the market.  
(iv)  Prepare  the  regulatory  instruments  required  for  monitoring  the  competitive 
generation market. This will include the reporting requirements of different market 
entities to the regulator regarding the functioning of the market and the guidelines 
for regulatory interventions to ensure proper functioning of the market. Explore the 
possibility  of  internalizing  environmental  externalities  through  regulatory 
instruments and fiscal incentives. 
(v)  Review  the  power  purchase  agreements  that  EVN  has  already  entered  into, 
especially with domestic IPPs. Recommend how these IPPs could participate in 
the proposed power market without having to renegotiate the power purchase 
agreements.  
(vi)  Propose a strategy to overcome the distortions prevalent in fuel markets (natural 
gas and coal)  and make specific recommendations regarding how to address the 
possibility of cross-subsidizing power produced by power plants owned by state-
owned fuel supply companies (Vina Coal and Petro Viet Nam).  
(vii)  Propose  dispute  resolution  mechanisms  and  enforcement  mechanisms  for 
regulatory  decisions,  taking  into  account  the  provisions  of  the  decree/decision 
establishing the regulator.     
 
D.  Stakeholder Consultation and Reporting Requirement 
 
5.   At the completion of task A, the consultants will present the findings and recommendations 
in relation to the overall sector restructuring process to stakeholders at a workshop. The feedback 
received will be incorporated into the final report on task A. Tasks B and C will be carried out in 
parallel after the completion of task A. The interim recommendations pertaining to tasks B and C

12   Appendix 3 
 
 
will be presented to stakeholders at two separate workshops and the feedback received will be 
incorporated in the final reports on tasks B and C. Each workshop will be preceded by a tripartite 
meeting between the Asian Development Bank, the Ministry of Industry, and the consultants to 
review the progress of implementation of the TA.  
 
6.   An inception report will be submitted 2 weeks after the commencement of the assignment 
outlining the detailed work plan for the assignment and the consultants’ initial observations on the 
reform process. The consultants will submit interim reports (2 months after the commencement of 
task A and 6 months after the commencement of tasks B and C) on each task prior to the 
respective workshop for review and comment by stakeholders. The final deliverables of the TA will 
be  three  separate  reports  on  tasks  A,  B,  and  C  to  be  submitted  4  months  after  the 
commencement of task A and 8 months after the commencement of tasks B and C. The team 
leader is responsible for preparing all key deliverables.
